chaining of large language models so for example you have um there's a product
that Google's jigsaw incubator team created that was called perspective Ai
and they created this product to moderate human responses on online
forums to weed out offensive language and inappropriate language and things
like that um but to do it in a much more sophisticated way than simply a key word filter with for
example what they have now done is they've actually put this as a moderating layer on top of other large
language models so that it can help ensure that that large language model does not um violate its its own

actually being used the the prospective AI model has been used by Google meta open eye anthropic and others where the
output of their large language model is then fed through prospective AI which moderates the content and if it passes
the inspection of the prospective AI moderating layer it's then passed on to the user otherwise it's suppressed and
the user doesn't see that answer um so this is really interesting and and there's experimentation going on right
now with actually using multiple large language models almost in a competitive form where different models are given
the same prompt or the same query and then a model sitting on top of them
gathers up the responses and Compares them and picks the one that it feels is
the best response so we're going to see a lot more work around how these different models can be combined um to
to add value in new ways so um so all of this sounds really good
right I mean who wouldn't love to have large language models that can help you with every aspect of your job and make

be aware that large language models can hallucinate that is they can say things
that simply aren't true they can give us biased answers and at the root there is
no concept of Truth or accuracy in a large language model I think one of the
the people who said it very well was a woman named kazzy corov and I probably

not a person it's just a pattern finding thing labeler which is a pretty interesting
way of putting it it really just builds strings of language out of patterns that has learned from previous strings of
language it's looked at and it has no concept and no mechanism of ensuring
those strings of language are anything other than well-formed languages so there's no guarantee that they're going

output was phrased and articulated very clearly it just wasn't correct um so
that's one of the challenges uh the the other part of the challenge is that large language models were trained as I

large language model is based on massive volumes of data but it doesn't know
anything about your business specifically except to the extent that your business your public documentation

no inherent advantage over other people who are using the same large language model as you and that's something to be

are just one form of artificial intelligence and what we see is for most

also understanding which model you're going to use as you saw earlier there
are literally hundreds if not a thousand different large language models
available in private domain and public domain and one of the things that we
really need to understand is how to match the model to the problem one of the uh idiosyncrasies of these models is
that people tend to train them and test them against a number of different benchmarks and there is a constantly
increasing set of public benchmarks that you can Benchmark a large language model
against and of course like all of these things what we tend to see is as
performance goes up against a particular Benchmark for a model that model also
suffers in performance on other benchmarks so you end up with a situation where you've got some models

use case is a big part of the battle and then finally we I've hammered home a number
of times the point that a generic model isn't going to give you a lasting Advantage so you need to take steps to
control modify and customize the way that that model behaves and so these are
a whole other conversation about what how these accomplished but if you look at things like prompt engineering which
is um a fancy word for really knowing how to ask the types of questions that
you want to ask of the model and and make that um make the model give you the
kind of answer you want through fine tuning of a model which is uh presenting
additional information to the model that will change the manner in which it responds you can change the types of um
language it uses you can change the way it expresses itself through finetuning there's uh additional forms of things
like context injection which is where you are adding additional documents that
have been analyzed to the underlying model of the under underlying Foundation
model so you're basically expanding the knowledge base if you want to call it that of the model um and then finally in

value of these uh as we go down that list they get more and more effective but they also get considerably more
timec consuming and expensive so um custom model development is not something that's accessible for most use
cases um but there will be situations where it's appropriate and then last but not least
and probably the biggest and most fundamental thing that you can do is pay attention to the data that you're using
with a model so when whether you're fine-tuning a model you're doing context injection or you're doing uh um custom
development the data that you are using to augment your model absolutely matters
uh the model is only as good as as the data that it's trained on and and this is the hard reality of this
and putting model putting data into a model is really complicated so um we
have problems with data quality which is the accuracy and consistency of the data that you want to introduce to the model
as as well as data availability and the availability problem I I had um a

this data becomes a major expense and stumbling block and one of the the
paradoxes of this is if you look at data management as it's been practiced over
the last decade in most organizations the focus has been on databases and
structure data making sure our transaction data is right our customer Master data is correct Etc we have
traditionally in most Industries put less emphasis on the quality the
structure and the availability of this unstructured data of documents that are
um spread on document Management systems and SharePoint and emails of textual data of audio data video data Etc this
